result.execSummary:
Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Randal M. Herrick Jr.

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Transcript of Sentencing Hearing held on October 20, 2015 before Judge Wambach

Cases 15CF267 and 14CF219 called together at 1:50pm [mo]
Defendant Randal M. Herrick Jr. in court, in custody with Attorney Thomas J Laitsch.   ADA Jeffrey Shock appears for the State of Wisconsin.

As to Case 15CF267(Status Conference occurs):
Atty. Laitsch indicates that this case is part of the sentencing of Case 14CF219

As to Case 14CF219(Sentencing & Restitution Hearing occurs):
On Joint Motion of the Parties, the Court reads-in and dismisses Case 15CF267
The Court and Counsel discuss allowing victim of Dismissed Counts to address the Court; the Court recites Case Law, The Court concludes that it will allow victim Becky KM to address the Court
Victim, Becky KM--makes a statement to the Court

Sentencing arguments given by ADA Shock 
--ADA Shock submits State's Exh. #1(Chart of Mr. Herrick's Prior Convictions)--offered and received

The Court does not order Mr Herrick to reimburse Anthem Blue Cross as part of this Criminal case
The Court finds that Mr. Leroy is entitled to $27,156.68 in restitution from Mr. Herrick 

recess:2:29pm--reconvene: 4:07pm[to allow the Court to call remainder of afternoon calendar]

The Court notes that it did review the Victim Impact Statements submitted by Becky KM and Mr. Leroy
Statements made by Ms. Lupkus and Ms. Bowes on behalf of Mr. Herrick 
Sentencing arguments given by Attorney Laitsch 
Statement made by Mr. Herrick 

On Count #1 the Court sentences Mr. Herrick to 2 years in the Wisconsin Prison System, consisting of 1 year 6 months of Initial Confinement and 6 months of Extended Supervision; this sentence is to begin FORTHWITH

On Count #4 the Court sentences Mr. Herrick to 2 years in the Wisconsin Prison System consisting of 1 year of Initial Confinement and 1 year of Extended Supervision, this sentence is to be served consecutive to Count #1.

As to Count #1:
The Court finds that the Defendant is NOT eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program "Boot Camp".
The Court finds that the Defendant is NOT eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.
 
As to Count #4: 
The Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program "Boot Camp".
The Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.

The Court finds that Mr. Herrick's ability to pay towards restitution over the course of extended supervision is $7,500

The Court orders as conditions of Extended Supervision:
--On Count #1: to pay costs of $243  plus the $200 DNA surcharge
--On Count #4: to pay costs of $268 plus the $250 DNA surcharge
--to pay officer overtime in the amount of $119.28
--to pay restitution to Nicholas Leroy in the amount of $7500
--to pay 10% restitution processing fee
--All other conditions of Extended Supervision are at the discretion of the Agent


As to Both Counts: Days credit for time already served:  0  days
Felony Firearm and Voting-rights prohibitions/warnings given
Explanation of Determinate Sentence form given to the Defendant
recess: 5:20pm 

[[Post-Hearing//Off-Record: The Clerk clarifies with the Court that Mr. Herrick owes Mr. Leroy $27,156.68 is restitution; Mr. Herrick is obligated to pay the $7500 during Extended Supervision, the remainder is to be converted to a Civil Judgement against Randal Herrick in favor of Mr. Leroy]]

Case called at 10:42am [mo]
Defendant Randal M. Herrick not in court.   DA Susan Happ appears for the State of Wisconsin.
recess:10:34am--reconvene:10:47am [to allow Mr. Herrick to be brought from the jail]

Defendant Randal Herrick now appears in custody; all other appearances remain the same.

With no objections, The Court appoints Attorney Laitsch to represent Mr. Herrick on this case.
The Court schedules this case for a status conference on 10/20/15 at 1:30pm (Mr. Herrick has another scheduled case on this date and time)
recess: 10:56am

NEXT: Status Conference on 10/20/15 at 1:30pm
State Public Defender Determination of Financial Eligibility - Defendant not eligible.
Scheduling Notice; Your Right to Legal Representation in a Criminal or Criminal Traffic Case
Copy of 8/17/15 minutes provided to Judge Wambach re: Mr. Herrick's Huber on case 14CF389

[MK] case called at 1:23pm. 
Defendant Randal M. Herrick appears via videoconferencing from the Jefferson County Jail, in custody, with Attorney Elizabeth Svehlek (PD appears for bond purposes only; Mr. Herrick does not qualify for PD representation).  
Public Service Prosecutor Melanie Flint appears for the State of Wisconsin.  
Attorney Svehlek indicates that she believes the videoconferencing system is sight and sound sufficient. 
Mr. Herrick indicates that the date of birth and address on the Criminal Complaint are correct, however he is currently an inmate in the Jefferson County Jail on Huber Release. 

Right to counsel is given. 
Service of Complaint admitted, reading waived, the charge and maximum penalties are recited. 
Preliminary Hearing time limits are waived by both parties.

During arguments on bond, after Attorney Svehlek indicates that Mr. Herrick has reported to her that he has spoken with the Jail Sergeants and because there is nothing in the existing Bond to indicate Mr. Herrick was to have absolute sobriety, he will still be on Huber Release in Case 14CF389, the Court indicates to the clerk that a memo is to be sent to Judge Wambach promptly, informing Judge Wambach that the Defendant in case #14CF389 is an inmate who reported to the County Jail with alcohol in his system and Sergeant intends to release him on Huber, so that Judge Wambach has awareness of this.   

The Court requires a $5,000  Signature Bond, with conditions:
--no possession or ingestion of alcohol
--no presence in bars, taverns, liquor stores
recess 1:27pm. 

NEXT: (1) Pretrial Conference on 9/9/15 at 2:20pm (2) Status Conference on 10/6/15 at 10:30am
